Loren Connors.title: Moonlight
Loren Connors.label: Chapter Music
Loren Connors.about:
The extraordinary creative partnership of New Haven, Connecticut duo Kath Bloom and Loren Connors has haunted fans of fragile folk and blues since the early 80s.
Kath taught herself guitar during shifts as a janitor at a New Haven cemetery, while Loren’s free-form idiosyncratic style had been developing since the late 60s. Between 1981 and 1984, the duo recorded two live and four studio albums, mostly self-released in tiny quantities.
Early on, their music mixed folk and blues traditionals with a handful of Kath’s vulnerable, moving originals. By the later albums the songs were all Kath’s - her fragile voice and subdued finger- picking set against Loren’s abstract but always supportive playing. Together the duo created a sound almost impossibly emotional and haunting.
Moonlight emerged as the duo’s final album in 1984, in an edition of 200-300 copies. As her creativity accelerated, Kath’s songs became looser and more intuitive, but Moonlight contains an early version of one of Kath’s most beloved songs, Come Here. Loren’s longterm collaborator Robert Crotty contributes electric guitar to a couple of tracks.
By 1984, Kath was married with a young son, and Connors was entering a new relationship, so the duo found themselves drifting apart. Kath did not release anything again until a 1993 solo cassette Love Explosion, but then developed a devoted cult following through the pivotal use of a new recording of Come Here in Richard Linklater’s 1995 film Before Sunrise.
Kath has since released three solo albums on Chapter Music (Finally in 2005, Terror in 2008 and Pass Through Here in 2015), as well as the Bloom tribute album Loving Takes This Course, featuring covers by the likes of Bill Callahan, Mark Kozelek, Devendra Banhart, Josephine Foster and many more.
Loren also retreated from music for a period until re-emerging in the late 1980s. He is now recognised as a pioneering guitar explorer, and has worked with the likes of Thurston Moore, Keiji Haino, Jim O’Rourke and many more.
After reissuing four of Kath & Loren’s landmark albums on CD in the late 2000s, Chapter has now embarked on the first ever vinyl reissues for these remarkable records. Another 1984 album Restless Faithful Desperate was reissued in 2018, while 1983’s Sand In My Shoe will be released alongside Moonlight in October 2019.
Moonlight includes five digital-only bonus tracks of rare 1984 live recordings, as well as comprehensive digital liner notes.
Loren Connors.credits: released October 4, 2019

Loren Connors.title: Restless Faithful Desperate
Loren Connors.label: Chapter Music
Loren Connors.about:
The extraordinary creative partnership of New Haven, CT duo Kath Bloom and Loren Connors has haunted psych-folk fans since the early 80s.
Kath taught herself guitar during shifts as a janitor at a New Haven cemetery, while Loren’s free-form idiosyncratic style had been developing since the late 60s. Between 1981 and 1984, the duo recorded two live and four studio albums, mostly self-released in tiny quantities.
Early on, their music mixed folk and blues traditionals with a handful of Kath’s vulnerable, moving originals. By the later albums the songs were all Kath’s - her fragile voice and subdued finger-picking set against Loren’s abstract but always supportive playing. Together the duo created a sound almost impossibly emotional and haunting.
Restless Faithful Desperate emerged in 1984, in an edition of 200-300 copies. As her creativity accelerated, Kath’s songs became looser and more intuitive, but Restless contains one of her most gorgeously realised compositions, Look at Me. Loren’s long-term collaborator Robert Crotty contributed electric guitar on a couple of tracks
By 1984, however, Kath was married with a young son, and Connors was entering a new relationship, so after 1984 the duo found themselves drifting apart. Kath did not release anything again until a 1993 solo cassette Love Explosion, but then developed a devoted cult following through the pivotal use of her song Come Here in Richard Linklater’s 1995 film Before Sunrise.
Kath has since released three solo albums on Chapter Music (Finally in 2005, Terror in 2008 and Pass Through Here in 2015), as well as the Bloom tribute album Loving Takes This Course, featuring covers by the likes of Bill Callahan, Mark Kozelek, Devendra Banhart, Josephine Foster and many more.
Loren also retreated from music for a period until re-emerging in the late 1980s. He is now recognised as a pioneering guitar explorer, and has worked with the likes of Thurston Moore, Keiji Haino, Jim O’Rourke and many more.
After reissuing four of Kath & Loren’s landmark albums on CD in the late 2000s, Chapter now embarks on the first ever vinyl reissues for these remarkable records. Expect more volumes in early 2019.
This album includes a digital-only bonus track of 1982 compilation track Tell Him. Each LP will include digital bonus material.

Loren Connors.title: Restless Faithful Desperate / Moonlight
Loren Connors.label: Chapter Music
Loren Connors.about:
HAVE JUST FOUND SOME ORIGINAL 2009 2CDs SO HAVE PUT THIS ON BANDCAMP FOR THE FIRST TIME!
FROM THE ORIGINAL 2009 PRESS RELEASE
Restless Faithful Desperate/Moonlight is the second of Chapter Music’s double disc reissues by extraordinary early 80s folk duo Kath Bloom and Loren Connors.
Meeting in 1976 in their hometown New Haven, CT, Kath Bloom and Loren Connors formed a creative partnership that has haunted psych-folk fans ever since, releasing six albums of fragile avant- garde folk-blues in miniscule quantities, all of which now change hands for huge sums.
At first, Kath would act out monologues while Loren played his free-form guitar, extrapolated from Mississippi Delta and Chicago blues, but gradually he and Kath’s performances became more song-based. Kath began practising guitar among the headstones of New Haven’s Grove Street cemetery, while Loren’s idiosyncratic style had been developing since the 1960s.
After self-releasing two limited edition live albums, the duo recorded Sing The Children Over for tiny Boston label Ambiguous Records in 1982, and then in 1983 self-released fourth album Sand In My Shoe. Early on, their albums mixed traditional folk and blues songs with a handful of Kath’s vulnerable, moving originals. But by the later albums, the songs were all Kath’s - her fragile voice and subdued finger-picked guitar set against Loren’s abstract playing, skittering, sometimes atonal but always intui- tively supportive. Together the duo created a sound almost impossibly emotional and haunting, unlike anything created before or since.
Their last two albums Restless Faithful Desperate and Moonlight both emerged in 1984, in editions of 200-300 copies on Loren’s St. Joan label. As her creativity accelerated, so Kath’s songs became looser, more intuitive, with a darkening of tone and an eventual abandonment of intent to shape the music. The songs were still there, however - Restless contains one of her most gorgeous compositions Look at Me, while Moonlight includes an early version of Kath’s signature tune Come Here.
By 1984 Kath was married with a young son, and Connors himself was entering a new relationship, so the duo found themselves drifting apart. Kath did not release anything again until a 1993 solo cassette Love Explosion, but then developed a devoted cult following through the pivotal use of Come Here in Richard Linklater’s 1995 film Before Sunrise. She has since released two solo albums on Chapter Music, as well as the recent Bloom tribute album Loving Takes This Course, featuring covers by the likes of Devendra Banhart, Bill Callahan, Mark Kozelek, Josephine Foster and many more.
Loren also retreated from music for a period until re-emerging in the late 1980s. He is now recognised as a pioneering guitar explorer, and has worked with the likes of Thurston Moore, Keiji Haino, Jim O’Rourke and many more.
After a quarter of a century, Kath Bloom and Loren Connors’ incredible recordings are finally available again. The reissue includes extensive liner notes, original photos and artwork, and six bonus tracks taken from a rare 1982 compilation and an unreleased 1984 live session!
“Devastating songwriting...the cult singer-songwriter's weary voice gnaws into the listener's hide.” - NPR
“Unlike anything else of its time in its mix of the conventional and avant-garde” - Allmusic
“(Kath Bloom) is teetering on a Vashti Bunyan level of rebirth” - Pitchfork
Loren Connors.credits: released October 31, 2009

Loren Connors.title: Sand In My Shoe
Loren Connors.label: Chapter Music
Loren Connors.about:
The extraordinary creative partnership of New Haven, CT duo Kath Bloom and Loren Connors has haunted psych-folk fans since the early 80s.
Kath taught herself guitar during shifts as a janitor at a New Haven cemetery, while Loren’s free-form idiosyncratic style had been developing since the late 60s. Between 1981 and 1984, the duo recorded two live and four studio albums, mostly self-released in tiny quantities.
Early on, their music mixed folk and blues traditionals with a handful of Kath’s vulnerable, moving originals. By the later albums the songs were all Kath’s - her fragile voice and subdued finger- picking set against Loren’s abstract but always supportive playing. Together the duo created a sound almost impossibly emotional and haunting.
Kath & Loren’s first two albums in 1981-82 were live recordings, released via Loren’s Daggett Records label. Next came 1982’s Sing The Children Over on Massachusetts label Ambiguous Records. Then Sand In My Shoe emerged in 1983 as the first release on Loren’s new St. Joan label, in an edition of 200-300 copies with handmade sleeves.
Restless Faithful Desperate and Moonlight followed in 1983-84, before the prodigious duo parted ways. Kath did not release any- thing again until a 1993 solo cassette Love Explosion, but then developed a devoted cult following through the pivotal use of her song Come Here in Richard Linklater’s 1995 film Before Sunrise.
Kath has since released three solo albums on Chapter Music (Finally in 2005, Terror in 2008 and Pass Through Here in 2015), as well as the Bloom tribute album Loving Takes This Course, featuring covers by the likes of Bill Callahan, Mark Kozelek, Devendra Banhart, Josephine Foster and many more.
Loren also retreated from music for a period until re-emerging in the late 1980s. He is now recognised as a pioneering guitar explorer, and has worked with the likes of Thurston Moore, Keiji Haino, Jim O’Rourke and many more.
After reissuing Kath & Loren’s four landmark studio albums on CD in the late 2000s, Chapter has now embarked on the first ever vinyl reissues for these remarkable records. Restless Faithful Desperate was reissued in 2018, while Moonlight will be released alongside Sand In My Shoe in October 2019.
Sand In My Shoe includes five digital-only bonus tracks, from 1982 live EP Pushin’ Up Daisies, as well as comprehensive digital liner notes.
Loren Connors.credits: released October 4, 2019

Loren Connors.title: Sing the Children Over/Sand In My Shoe
Loren Connors.label: Chapter Music
Loren Connors.about:
Original 2008 press release:
Chapter music is honoured to announce the first of two double disc reissues by extraordinary early 80s folk duo Kath Bloom and Loren Connors.
Meeting in 1976 in their hometown New Haven, CT, Kath Bloom and Loren Connors formed a creative partnership that has haunted psych-folk fans ever since, releasing six albums of fragile avant-garde folk-blues in minuscule quantities, all of which now change hands for huge sums.
At first, Kath would act out monologues while Loren played his free-form guitar, extrapolated from Mississippi Delta and Chicago blues. But while Loren worked on his now legendary nine volume series Unaccompanied Acoustic Guitar Improvisations, he and Kath’s performances gradually became more song-based. Kath began practicing guitar among the headstones of New Haven’s Grove Street cemetery, while Loren’s idiosyncratic style had been developing since the 1960s.
By the early 80s, after self-releasing two limited edition live albums, the duo were playing occasionally outside of New Haven, and soon Boston independent label Ambiguous Records approached them to record their first studio effott. Acclaimed jazz critic and music historian Nat Hentoff wrote sensitive, insightful liner notes and Sing The Children Over emerged in 1982.
Sing The Children Over mixed traditional folk and blues songs with Kath’s originals, and tracks such as It’s So Hard To Come Home and The Breeze/My Baby Cries revealed Kath to be an accomplished and moving songwriter. It also set up the dynamic template that she and Loren would follow over their remaining recordings – Kath’s fragile voice and subdued finger-picked guitar set against Loren’s play- ing: abstract, skittering, sometimes atonal but always intuitively supportive. Together the duo created a sound almost impossibly emotional and haunting, one unlike anything created before or since.
Kath and Loren released three more albums - Sand In My Shoe, Restless Faithful Desperate and Moonlight, in 1983 and 84 - all on Loren’s own Saint Joan label in editions of 200-300 copies, and all featuring noth- ing but Kath’s original compositions. The last two albums will also be released by Chapter Music as a double disc set in August.
By 1984, however, Kath was married with a young son, and Connors himself was entering a new relationship, so the duo found themselves drifting apart. After she and Loren’s final album Moonlight in 1984, Kath did not release anything again until a 1993 solo cassette Love Explosion. She then developed a devoted cult following through the pivotal use of her song Come Here in Richard Linklater’s 1995 film Before Sunrise, and has released two solo albums on Chapter Music, including the brand new Terror.
Loren also retreated from music for a period, focusing on other forms of writing until re-emerging in the late 1980s. He is now recognised as a pioneering guitar explorer, and has worked with the likes of Thurston Moore, Keiji Haino, Jim O’Rourke and many more.
And now, after almost 25 years, Kath Bloom and Loren Connors’ original recordings are again available to be soaked up, marveled at and relished. Both double disc sets include extensive liner notes, original photos and artwork, and a treasure trove of bonus tracks!
Loren Connors.credits: released July 9, 2008

Loren Connors.title: Angels That Fall
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
A haunting and volcanic suite of electric guitar and piano from the modern master of the avant blues and the abstract -- Loren Connors. Angels That Fall slips deeper into Loren's headspace where vocalists in glissando and the swelling romanticism of chamber strings echo from beyond this mortal plane. Transcribed through Connors effect-laden six strings, he carries the listener from bluesy violence to sadness, hope and a piano coda.
Angels That Fall was recorded May 2016 at First Unitarian Congregational Society in Brooklyn, NY.
Loren Connors.credits:
released August 25, 2017
Loren Connor - electric guitar, piano

Loren Connors.title: As Roses Bow: Collected Airs 1992-2002
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
As Roses Bow: Collected Airs 1992-2002 is Loren Connors' assembly of his most melodically rich and stunning miniature compositions. Inspired by O'Carolan's airs and other Irish airs of the past, these works, recorded during a ten year period, are melded with the distinctly personal and iconoclast adaptation of Connors' blues.
These 43 pieces are Connors' complete airs, culled from 10 albums (eight of which are out of print) and one single, including his groundbreaking Hell's Kitchen Park (Black Label, 1993), Moonyean (Road Cone, 1994), as well as obscure titles like St. Vincent's Newsboy Home (Item Recordings, 1998) and Lullaby (Carbon, 2001) plus four unreleased airs. Nearly the entire critically heralded Airs (Road Cone 1999) is remastered and included as well. A timeless collection of the most gorgeous and accessible work from one of America's most iconoclast artists. Vocalist and long-time collaborator Suzanne Langille appears on four pieces.
Also includes pieces from Five Points EP (Table of the Elements, 1994), 9th Avenue (Black Label 1995), Calloden Harvest (Road Cone, 1997), Evangeline (Road Cone, 1998), Standing Upright on a Curve (1998), and Sails (Table of the Elements, 2006). Remastered by Jim O'Rourke.
Loren Connors.credits: released November 5, 2007

Loren Connors.title: At The Old Factory
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
At The Old Factory is a raw snapshot of a 1999 performance between Darin Gray and Loren Connors at the original Knitting Factory in Downtown New York City. It is one of the earliest live performances of what would become an intense few years of musical partnership.
At this point the two had already recorded their debut album, The Lost Mariner, and Gray was part of the big band ensemble for Connors & Alan Licht's Hoffman Estates LP with producer Jim O'Rourke.
At The Old Factory was released as a bonus 7-inch included in the 10-year anniversary LP reissue of The Lost Mariner.

Cover art -- Katie Leming
Recorded April 22, 1999

Loren Connors.title: At The Top Of The Stairs
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Acclaimed guitar duo Loren Connors and Alan Licht celebrate their 30-year collaboration in 2023 with the release of their eighth album — At The Top Of The Stairs —and a series of performances. The duo will hold a two-night residence at Cafe OTO in London on May 5 and 6.
Across the decades, their improvisations became increasingly abstract and atonal while maintaining complex, ethereal arrangements. The harmonious blend of Licht's meticulously crafted feedback and harmonic patterns with Connors' ghostly blue tones remains the core sound of this partnership.
At the Top Of The Stairs was recorded live in 2018. Across two side-long pieces, the duo ascends slowly, through layers of atmospheric tension punctuated by thunderous waves of Connors’ effects.
For fifty years, Connors’s adaptation of acoustic Delta blues has transmuted into miniature grayscale compositions and howling riffs. His collaborators include Oren Ambarchi, Keiji Haino, and Kim Gordon. Connors’ second book of his paintings Night of Rain (Recital) was released last year.
Rock/experimental musician Alan Licht was a member of the bands Love Child, Run On, and Lee Ranaldo & the Dust, and has released a range of acclaimed rock and experimental albums. He is an author with books published by Rizzoli, W.W. Norton, Faber & Faber, and Blank Forms.
Loren Connors.credits:

Loren Connors.title: Beautiful Dreamer
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Beautiful Dreamer is a two-part suite dedicated to Steve Dalachinsky -- an original among New Yorkers and everyone else; an indefatigable supporter of the avant garde; an ingenious poet; and a close friend to Loren Connors. Connors recorded these two solo guitar pieces shortly before Dalachinsky’s passing in September 2019.
Afterward, Connors returned to the music, and for the first time, used post-production to transform his real-time improvisations into an ethereal soundwork. It is unmistakably Connors -- a rich, ghostly tone birthed from the blues -- yet a new direction where slowness reveals a spectrum of shifting notes like a small choir, from rumbling baritones to vibrating sopranos. Beautiful Dreamer equally honors the dreams of Dalachinsky and captures the suspension of the Auguste Rodin dancer on the cover.
Loren Connors.credits:
released June 5, 2020
Electric Guitar, Producer – Loren Connors
Audio Mastering – Taylor Deupree
Illustration – Auguste Rodin
Photography – Chaz Prymek

Loren Connors.title: Blues: The "Dark Paintings" of Mark Rothko
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Blues: The ‘Dark Paintings’ of Mark Rothko is one of Loren Connors’ most cherished and sought after albums. Originally released in a handmade edition of 300 copies on Connors’ own St. Joan imprint in January 1990 under the name Guitar Roberts -- Blues has been unavailable in any form until now.
At time of its release, Connors was still an inscrutable guitarist whose matchless and alien rendering of the blues was just gaining recognition despite more than a dozen solo and collaborative releases since 1978. Connors’ classic, song-based In Pittsburgh had only been available for three months when Blues welcomed the new decade with its reformation of the blues as minimalist lines and tone; a compound of influences spanning Louisiana guitarist Robert Pete Johnson to painter Mark Rothko.
"Moving with the slow, stately weirdom we expect of Connors' late '80s sound, the music is all shards, all pokes in the eye, as though Rothko's gray scale had exploded, sending shrapnelized paint rocketing through your brain," music historian Byron Coley writes in the liner notes of this reissue. "Just as Connors' notes ricochet hauntedly through its recesses."
For this reissue, engineer Taylor Deupree restored the audio to Connors’ specifications of how these seven instrumentals were intended to sound. Cover art is an untitled 1969 Rothko work -- a painting that influenced the album. The original LP jacket is replicated as a glossy inner sleeve. New liner notes by Coley chart Connors' development and the influence Rothko had on him as a guitarist.
Digital download includes PDF of original and reissue album art.
LP cover image by Mark Rothko Untitled, 1969 © 1998 Kate Rothko Prizel & Christopher Rothko / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York
Loren Connors.credits: released May 12, 2015

Loren Connors.title: Domain Of The Wind
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Domain Of The Wind is a 22-minute solo electric guitar suite from Loren Connors. At times thunderous, Connors’ strikes of hand shatter melodies as single notes and chords come whipping by. The mastery use of simple effects further transfigures Connors’ ever changing blues structure into a harrowing transmission of smeared, reverberant tones.
This is not Connors' past space music, nor his expedition into nothingness -- but something rather heavy. The music here, like Mark Mahaney’s portrait of Connors adorning the cover, is deeply human and a reflection of life and the unknown future. Edition of 300 copies on black 10-inch vinyl -- only available directly from Family Vineyard.
Loren Connors.credits:

Loren Connors.title: Hell's Kitchen Park
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Originally released 1993 on Black Label, Black 1 CD, as Loren MazzaCane. Reissued digitally by Family Vineyard in 2007. Features Suzanne Langille -- vocals, lyrics -- on "Child" and "Brigid’s Song."
Not only the first of the Black Label titles but the hands down classic of Connors' Venusian / street story / tear suspended electric blues. Based on the New York City Irish-American slum known as Hell’s Kitchen of the late 19th and early 20th century, Connors summons the freight trains, the death, the violence, and the poverty into an alluring and stark six-string portrait. Essential!
Liner notes: "The NYC Irish-American slum known as Hell’s Kitchen was in the late 19th and early 20th century, the most desperate slum in U.S. history. The level of neglect, poverty, disease, violence and pollution that existed there still remains unequalled. Eleventh Avenue, with its freight train traffic, once was known as Death Avenue."
Loren Connors.credits: released July 1, 1993

Loren Connors.title: Into The Night Sky
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
"The balance here between peace and struggle is what makes this music unique and special. You do not want it to end because it speaks directly to your heart." — Bruce Lee Gallanter, Downtown Music Gallery
Into the Night Sky is the sixth album from avant guitarists Alan Licht and Loren Connors, the first after 2003's In France (FBWL). Since 1993 these New York City artists have evolved an instrumental dialogue merging shades of electric blues and minimalism. These two epic pieces -- one from 1996, the other from 2006 -- recorded live in concert clearly show far their desolate sound world grew over a decade of collaboration while the core of layered guitar complexities and alien melodies remain. The atmosphere conjured by the Licht-Connors duo is unmistakable -- the ebb of eloquently shaped feedback -- while the harmonic patterns recall 20th Century classical music.
Active since the early 1990s, Licht has worked with a veritable who's who of the experimental world, from free jazz legends to iconic composers while performing in Text of Light and an ongoing duo with Aki Onda. Since 1978 Connors has released dozens of acclaimed and sought-after LPs documenting his singular adaption of the blues and forging his place as one of America's most iconoclastic artists.
Track 1 recorded Nov. 23, 1996, at Mercury Lounge.
Track 2 recorded March 24, 2006, at Yoga Sutra.
Loren Connors.credits:
released February 23, 2010
Electric guitar: Alan Licht
Electric guitar: Loren Connors

trackinfo.label: Family Vineyard

Loren Connors.title: Leone
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Leone is the first meeting of electric guitarists Loren Connors and Oren Ambarchi. It’s somewhat surprising it’s taken this long as these two are connected by ongoing collaborators, like Jim O’Rourke and Keiji Haino. Connors, for more than 40 years, has continued to develop an iconic sound tethered to radical permutations of the blues. Ambarchi’s own multi-decade transfiguration of the guitar inhabits a rarefied realm of abstracted tones and dissonance pitched between improvisation and composition.
This album, like its title, is a sum of parts: solo performances by Connors and Ambarchi bookend a duo. On “Lorn,” Connors unravels an aggressive ternary form, with an opening section wrapped in distortion and extreme phasing that contrasts against ghostly, distant single notes. This side-long piece is a dramatic six-string reimagination of Connors’ beloved vocal arias. Ambarchi’s “Nor,” supplants a guitar performance with melodic, shifting organ-like tones that are swallowed into a fluttering, glitchy squall. The harmonics and pace is similar in complexity to Ambarchi’s most recent album, Simian Angel (Editions Mego).
On “Ronnel,” the duo, each audio landscape created by the two slowly rotates and overlaps the other. Connors’ lightly traced blue and black notes are boldly punctuated by Ambarchi’s bright bass-like pulses and ebullient synthy colors. It’s as if each is drawing the others’ portrait on opposite sides of a translucent sheet.
Loren Connors.credits:
released January 29, 2021
Electric guitar — Loren Connors
Electric guitar — Oren Ambarchi
Recorded by —Bob Bellerue at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn, NY, November 15, 2017
Mixed and audio mastered by — Joe Talia
Vinyl cut by — Carl Saff
Cover, label illustrations by — Marissa Huber

trackinfo.title: Ronnel
trackinfo.label: Family Vineyard
trackinfo.credits: from Leone, released January 29, 2021

Loren Connors.title: Light
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Debut release by the perfectly matched guitar duo of Loren Connors and Clint Heidorn, recorded at Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral in Brooklyn during their first meeting. As in all Connors’ music the blues is a monophonic foundation permeating the atmosphere - and this is no exception. Yet as ghost tones flicker, shimmering melodies collapse into a speaker rattling brume that is epic and startling as Giacinto Scelsi’ string quartets. This is Connors and Heidorn as a chamber symphony propelled into electricity and six string clusters.
By now, Connors needs no introduction. The music of the Brooklyn-based artist was recently described by Jon Dale as "a loneliness that’s almost devastating in its purity. At its best, Connors’ music works at a cellular level, as though the fundamental nature of the piece is implicit in the very first note played: a flower just ready to bloom."
Heidorn is a composer and guitarist based in Los Angeles, California. His first album, Atwater, was released on his own Ashes, Ashes Publishing imprint in October of 2011. Deeply personal, his music explores simple melodies, themes of death and futility, and the sounds and impressions of his native Southern California. Atwater was followed in Fall 2012 with +33° 58' 41.85", -117° 49' 13.74", a limited edition release about the oak tree near his childhood home.
Light is Connor's third one-sided 12" released by Family Vineyard. Light was recorded recorded by Issue Project Room and mastered by Taylor Dupree at 12k Mastering.
Loren Connors.credits: released April 1, 2016

trackinfo.label: Family Vineyard

Loren Connors.title: Live In New York
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Live in New York is an album seemingly simple as its title. Yet Loren Connors -- captured here in cinéma vérité quality at two performances six days apart in November 2014 -- is anything but straightforward. During the past 40 years the guitarist has not only developed an iconic sound but continues to reshape it and challenge himself, and the listener, in accepting radical permutations of the blues.
Across these three pieces, Connors builds upon the vision captured on his last studio album, 2011's Red Mars, where transparent, ghostly notes slowly unravel against a canvas of black drones and funeral tolls. In addition -- maximist, distorted six-string solos, that were once a hallmark of Loren's early-90s performances, make a mighty return.
Loren Connors.credits:
released September 18, 2015
Loren Connors, electric guitar
Cover art by Connors.
Mastered by Taylor Deupree at 12k.

Loren Connors.title: Mercury

Loren Connors.title: Night Through: Singles & Collected Works 1976-2004
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
The essential collection of singles by legendary avant blues guitarist Loren Connors, one of America's most unique and challenging voices. "Night Through" spans four decades of Connors' recordings from the first acoustic solo 7" -- 'Ribbon o' Blues' on his own St. Joan imprint -- to rare singles issued by Table of the Elements, Road Cone, Father Yod, Menlo Park, Gyttja, Union Pole, and others, to his late 90s band Haunted House and recent acoustic recordings.
Seventy-one tracks span more than three and half hours of music: 12 7" singles, private CDR releases, collaborations with Suzanne Langille and Robert Crotty, compilation appearances, and 22 unreleased pieces including a 1959 recording by Connors' mother Mary Mazzacane. Remastered from the original tapes by Jim O'Rourke.
Comes with 24-page PDF booklet: detailed notes for each single, never before seen photographs, an essay by renowned Delta Blues scholar William Ferris and commentary from Connors, Langille, Road Cone's Mike Hinds and others.

Loren Connors.title: Nightfall
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Connors, now 75, remains an unstoppable force of creative expression. As his vast catalog of recordings continues to be reissued, and his visual art finds new audiences, he still moves forward—improvising in real time, forging his own path through a spectral, mutated form of the blues.
Nightfall is one of two new 10-inch records out now on Family Vineyard, and is among his most haunting. Dark and meditative, the music breathes in hushed tones, its melodies emerging from the shadows with Connors’ quiet, unshakable intensity. At times droning and immersive, at others achingly melodic, it carries a sense of time stretched and suspended—another chapter in Connors’ singular, ever-evolving sound world.
Connors music continues to be a world unto itself: delicate yet raw, evoking the ghosts of early American blues while dissolving into an ethereal, near-impressionistic haze. Connors’ guitar whispers, bends, and sighs, carving out space in a way that feels both ancient and entirely of the moment. His spontaneous compositions possess an emotional gravity that transcends technicality, drawing listeners into an intimate, dreamlike state.
Nightfall’s counterpart—Spitfire, another 10” out now, is the opposite—restless and alive with electricity.
Loren Connors.credits:

Recorded by Ian Douglas-Moore

Loren Connors.title: Red Mars
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Connors has long been heralded as one of the country's most inimitable guitar voices. Like kindred spirit John Fahey, Connors' legacy began by quietly self-releasing a series of raw and embryonic LPs. Since the late 1970s, Connors' use of haunted Delta Blues, minimalism and compositional underpinnings have become an avant-garde style synonymous to him. Along the way, musicians diverse as Chan Marshall, Keiji Haino, Darin Gray, Jim O'Rourke, Jandek, and Alan Licht have sought Connors as a musical partner on record and stage.
Red Mars is the first CD of new solo music by the New York City guitarist since 2004's The Departing of a Dream Vol III: Juliet. Since that time, Connors' unmistakable electric blues style presented on album has changed somewhat -- from multilayer tape-recorded pieces to spontaneous live performances. The five pieces here, a suite to the Red Planet, are filled of the cinematic pacing, lyricism and a palette of phantom tones that hoist Connors to a stunning new peak. Portuguese bassist Margarida Garcia joins Connors on the opening journey, introducing a dialogue unique in its ambiance as its entwined mystery and melodies. Features cover artwork by Connors.
© Loren Connors and Family Vineyard. All rights reserved.
To purchase Loren Connors on CD, please visit www.family-vineyard.com.D

Loren Connors.title: Robert Crotty with Me: Loren's Collection (1979-1987)
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
"I would go as far as to say that the few recordings that exist of these Robert Crotty sessions are among the finest and most beautiful blues documents of all time." -- Loren Connors
In the years 1978 to 1981, Robert Crotty would show up on Loren Connors’ doorstep in New Haven, Connecticut with his tiny, almost toy guitar. The two would then spend hours playing acoustic blues, the likes of which was absolutely staggering in its truthfulness.
"Robert Crotty with Me: Loren’s Collection (1979-1987)" is the first anthology of the late bluesman’s work, as selected by his former playing partner. These are the unheard tapes of Crotty and Connors communing with the spirits of Delta and County Blues through their own revisions of standards and tingle-inducing improvisations. These also some of the legendary Connors' earliest available recordings showing the development of iconoclast guitar style and vocal moan.
Crotty was a New Haven lifer and linchpin of the region’s blues scene yet, he never achieved much recognition outside local bars and house parties -- until now. The album features never before heard recordings, unseen photos, liner notes by Connors and Crotty’s brother
Loren Connors.credits:
released December 8, 2017
Robert Crotty, acoustic guitar, lead vocals
Loren Connors, acoustic guitar, backing vocals

Loren Connors.title: Spitfire
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Connors, now 75, remains an unstoppable force of creative expression. As his vast catalog of recordings continues to be reissued, and his visual art finds new audiences, he still moves forward—improvising in real time, forging his own path through a spectral, mutated form of the blues.
Spitfire is one of two new 10-inch records out now on Family Vineyard, it’s restless and alive with electricity. This is Connors at his most physical, wrenching sound from his guitar with forceful, percussive strikes. Notes crack and fracture, vibrating through the amplifier like sudden sparks. While still carrying his signature spectral quality, Spitfire moves with intent, never settling into meditation. It flickers, erupts, and fades like the last moments of a fire burning out.
Connors music continues to be a world unto itself: delicate yet raw, evoking the ghosts of early American blues while dissolving into an ethereal, near-impressionistic haze. Connors’ guitar whispers, bends, and sighs, carving out space in a way that feels both ancient and entirely of the moment. His spontaneous compositions possess an emotional gravity that transcends technicality, drawing listeners into an intimate, dreamlike state.
Spitfire’s counterpart—Nightfall, another 10” out now, is among Connors’ most haunting.

Loren Connors.title: St. Vincent's Newsboy Home
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Originally released 1999 on Item Recordings, 9901D CD, as Loren MazzaCane Connors. Reissued digitally by Family Vineyard in 2007. Recorded 1995-1998. Cover photo by Frederick Detlefsen, 1902.
"'Extra, extra! Read all about it!!' Everyone is familiar with this cry from the newspaper boys of the past. What is not commonly known, though, is that these boys, many of Irish background, were orphans without homes who all too often starved or froze to death in the street. A Room Catholic priest, Father Drumgoole, witnessed these tragedies and decided to build a home for orphaned kids, with he accompanied in the early years of this century. It was named St. Vincent's Newsboy Home, and today continues as the largest facility of its kind in the country." -- Loren Connors, 1999
"... one of the more obscure and hard-to-find entries in Connors' oeuvre. Strange, considering it's also one of his more gorgeous affairs, an all-too brief collection of Spartan guitar movements and bittersweet remembrances. Simply recorded, tracks like 'Angels of the Rooftops' and 'Doorsteps' echo off into the distance, as Connors carefully sounds his notes and allows them to linger ever so slightly." -- Other Music
Loren Connors.credits:
released November 6, 2007
Loren Connors, electric guitar

Loren Connors.title: The Curse of Midnight Mary
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
In 1981 guitarist Loren Connors took his tape recorder to the graveyard where the legendary Midnight Mary's grave lies in New Haven, Connecticut. The curse is: Anyone who gets caught in her graveyard past midnight will die the next day. But Connors, like a young fool, taped in that place, making this album.
Lost and forgotten, a cassette of this music -- made at Evergreen Cemetery -- was found by chance in 2008. Recorded between Connors' eight volume Unaccompanied Acoustic Guitar Improvisations LP series and the folk albums he would make with Kath Bloom, these nine pieces meld those distinct, haunting styles. Connors, singing in a trance like moan, reforms the Mississippi Delta blues on acoustic guitar with flashes of melodic hooks and a percussive guitar style that erupts into boogie-woogie riffs and other world spirituals.
It's an album for followers of Connors' spine tingling solo albums and his collaborations with Suzanne Langille or Jandek. Devotees of early 20th Century blues artists such as Blind Willie Johnson or Charley Patton will be equally enthralled. A rare and essential peak into the still mysterious early years of this American guitar master.
Loren Connors.credits:
released February 17, 2009
Acoustic guitar, artwork – Loren Connors
Mastered By – James Plotkin

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Reissue of master guitarist Loren Connors' modern classic The Departing of a Dream -- the first of what would become a three volume series based loosely as tribute to Miles Davis' "He Loved Him Madly." This album finds Connors exploring slowly churned darkened hues and signature ghost melodies, each collapsing onto themselves like echoes of Miles' muted trumpet.
Since the late 1970s, Connors' use of haunted Delta Blues, minimalism and compositional underpinnings have become an avant-garde style synonymous to him. When The Departing of a Dream was released as a CD in 2002 it signaled a dramatic growth in Connors' sound by combining electric, acoustic and bass guitar with the unsettling menage of rustling and ambient hiss. Remastered from the original tapes this new version extends the closing two-part suite "For NY 9/11/01" with the bonus track "Pretty as Ever," one of Connors’ most enduring melodies recontextualized as a final glimmer of hope in this blackened meditation.
Loren Connors.credits: released April 30, 2013

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream Vol. II
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Connors (aka Loren MazzaCane Connors) returns with the sequel to 2002's critically acclaimed The Departing of a Dream. The NYC blues guitarist, who has been recording and releasing albums since 1978, extends the theme (which was a loose tribute to Miles Davis' "He Loved Him Madly") into a fragile and floating eight-part piece of acoustic/electric/ and bass guitar mixed with field recordings and the unsettling menage of found sounds and ambient hiss. Whereas the first volume smoldered into a dark meditation with hardly a glimpse of light, Departing II offers notes of hope in the form of lifting melodic airs and distant bird calls. Replicating the sound of Davis' muted trumpet through extended guitar and recording techniques, Loren has created another startling and unique album of despair and awakening that can stand next to previous classics In Pittsburgh or Hell's Kitchen Park.
"... like an audio analogue to the canvases of Mark Rothko. The color is the blues, not because the music plays with the 12-bar form but because that's the mood, like tears suspended in a cloud that never breaks." -- Alec Hanley Bemis, LA Weekly
Loren Connors.credits:
released April 22, 2003

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream Vol. III: Juliet
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
"You can't hold on to things," Loren Connors says. "With great happiness comes great sorrow." So brings us to the spectrum that is Departing of a Dream Vol. III: Juliet. Like the previous volumes, Juliet is a tribute of sorts; and here the focus is clearly love, the kind of love willing to face desolation and ultimately death. Recorded in Connors's Brooklyn apartment, his electric guitar emits a pulsing web of blues notes that settle against the utterly intimate human ambience of a creaking chair, tumbling objects, smoke curled absence and his signature canvas of tape hiss. The story of Juliet and her Romeo is told in a lyrical outpouring that Connors has rarely shown in recent years, a style associated which his Rooms (1990) and Evangeline (1999) albums. Though the 20-minute album opener contains a devastating core of mire and foreboding that only Connors can create.
"Connors' gentle guitar music conjures up ghosts, representations of loneliness, sadness and introspection. Gentle mists hover above the unkempt gravestones of the disenfranchised souls of love lost. " -- Spencer Grady, Dusted
CD out of print.
Loren Connors.credits:
released May 11, 2014
Electric guitar: Loren Connors

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream Vol. V
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
After ten years, guitarist Loren Connors returns to his much acclaimed and beloved The Departing of a Dream series. Initially based loosely as tribute to Miles Davis' masterwork "He Loved Him Madly," Connors delves further into the inspiration to explore melody as a slow-moving spectrum of shades projected against a fragile, often decaying ambience.
Volume Five continues the theme, as Connors coaxes complex blues mutations and wide swathes of distant vibrating tones -- not unlike the expressionistic cry of Miles' horn. The flutter of voices and din that seep in between the sustained notes transform into a choir as only Connors can lead.
Loren Connors.credits: released May 6, 2016

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream Vol. VI
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Just months after reviving The Departing of a Dream series from a ten-year hiatus with the release of Volume V -- Loren Connors issues another movement of saturated guitar tones, dissonance and impermanence
Volume Six begins with the percussive sound of struck, muted strings, it's an unusually rhythmic effect for one of Connors solo recordings, writes Kurt Gottschalk in The Wire. But from there, Connors' guitar notes morph into gentle wisps of guitar sounds -- or as Connors himself describes: “just like the wind scattering the notes around."
Cover art by Connors.
Loren Connors.credits: released October 14, 2016

Loren Connors.title: The Departing of a Dream, Vol. VII
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
The Departing of a Dream, Vol. VII is the debut collaboration between two giants of the New York avant-garde ­— guitarist Loren Connors and saxophonist/trumpeter Daniel Carter. It's a gorgeous, languorous soundscape distilled from the darkest reaches of blues and jazz.
For nearly 17 years Connors has used the Departing series to continue his meditation on Miles Davis' epic "He Loved Him Madly" and expand his efforts to create disappearing music. The duo does just that, vanishing behind decaying trumpet drones and choral-like sheets of electric strings.
Carter and Connors both active since the mid-1970s only began performing together in the past year.
Carter is a master improviser on assorted horns and reeds and known as a member of the legendary NYC ecstatic/creative improvisational groups Other Dimensions In Music and Test and for accompanying everyone from Sun Ra, Yo La Tengo, and Matthew Shipp.
Connors has released records of his singular guitar improvisations and compositions since 1978. A few past Connors' albums contained saxes and more -- Come Night (1991) and Hoffman Estates (1998) --, but those were overdub, studio affairs. Here, Connors responds in real-time, processing effects and crafting an intimate world, shimmering like a black crystal.
Loren Connors.credits:
released May 3, 2019
Loren Connors - electric guitar
Daniel Carter - alto, tenor and soprano saxophones, trumpet
Jim O'Rourke - mix, mastering
Jef Mertens - cover image video still

Loren Connors.title: The Lost Mariner
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
The Lost Mariner is an improvised dialogue between avant blue legend Loren Connors and bassist Darin Gray (On Fillmore, Dazzling Killmen, Brise-Glace, Grand Ulena, etc.). Structure is there, but it roams as it sways, constantly adjusting and reinventing itself as the two react to its mysterious design. Their delicate whispers are as eloquent as many improvisors' loudest howls.
"Gray is an articulate and compelling melodist; in places Connors responds to him by twisting melancholy counter-melodies around his like ivory around wrought iron, but elsewhere he uses effects to turn his usually distinct notes into black, cavernous sound masses that aptly frame Gray's extrapolations." -- Bill Meyer, Signal to Noise
Loren Connors.credits:
released November 20, 1999
Electric guitar – Loren Connors
Electric bass – Darin Gray
Recorded at Smith Lee Studios, St. Louis, 1998 by John Katsafanas
Mixed and mastered at Steamroom, Chicago, 1999 by Jim O'Rourke
LP mastered at Salt Mastering, Brooklyn, 2009 by Paul Gold
Cover painting "Constance" (1896) by Albert Pinkham Ryder

This piece combines Loren’s deeply moving palette of melody with a masterful control of pace and drama that ends with a guitar coda twinkling in the darkness. It’s wrenching as his glorious ‘airs’ or the distortion mangled screams of his blues.

Loren Connors.title: This Past Spring
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about: "Loren MazzaCane tells us that this release -- his second with electric bassist Darin Gray has the best sound of all of his 20 plus releases, due to the excellent equipment at their disposal and the extremely quiet/respect of the audience at the Monroe County Public Library in Bloomington, Indiana in March of 2000. It is meant to be listened as an entire work, so that is the way it should be approached. That familiar haunting ghost-like melancholy tone and naked beauty is ever so elegant and touching. Darin Gray is perhaps Loren's most sympathetic partner -- he always balances the bottom with a warm and enchanting vibration which hovers in dark clouds and cushions the pain, terror and loneliness of Loren's majestic distortion -- digging deeper into the abyss and pouring out his guts for all to witness!" -- Bruce Lee Gallanter, Downtown Music Gallery, NYC

Loren Connors.title: untitled
Loren Connors.label: Family Vineyard
Loren Connors.about:
Tom Carter and Loren Connors are a pairing so obvious, it’s a mystery how it took this long to happen. Each has traversed the American underground on their own unique path. Carter co-founded acid-folk improvisers Charalambides in 1991 and Connors has been redefining his singular vision of the blues since the late 1970s.
On this debut non-titled LP, these guitar masters conjure a stunning, and at times labyrinthine, six-string tableau. Carter’s high-contrast spiral melodies sear through Connors’ expanding canvas of blacks and molten reds. It’s a startling and new language of psychedelic and avant blues that is a next step in Carter and Connor’s ongoing exploration of the guitar.
Loren Connors.credits:
released August 5, 2016
Tom Carter, electric guitar
Loren Connors, electric guitar

Loren Connors.title: 9th Avenue
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Mazzacane Connors' *9th Avenue* is a haunting exploration of minimalist blues, infused with an experimental edge that defies conventional boundaries. The album’s sparse guitar work, drenched in lo-fi aesthetics, creates an atmosphere that is both intimate and eerie, evoking the quiet, lonely streets of New York City after midnight. The subtle use of dissonance and delicate melodies reflects Connors' mastery of tension and release, drawing the listener into a world of deep introspection.
Each track on *9th Avenue* is a sonic vignette, capturing fleeting emotions and fragmented memories. The ambient soundscapes, reminiscent of impressionist art, allow the listener to fill in the spaces with their own imagination, making the experience deeply personal. Connors' ability to convey such profound emotion through minimalistic arrangements is a testament to his genius, making this album a timeless piece in the avant-garde blues genre.
The BPM across the tracks is generally slow, reflecting the contemplative mood that permeates the album. The use of subtle dynamics and the interplay between silence and sound further enhances the introspective quality of the music. *9th Avenue* is not just an album to listen to; it's an album to experience, offering a deep emotional journey for those willing to immerse themselves in its quiet beauty.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Thunderbird
trackinfo.about: Thunderbird opens the album with a mournful guitar melody that slowly unravels like a tale of forgotten memories. The slow BPM and the delicate strumming create a sense of melancholic introspection, setting the tone for the rest of the album. The track feels like a solitary walk through deserted streets, with each note echoing in the empty night air.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: 9th Ave
trackinfo.about: The title track, *9th Ave*, is a slow, brooding piece that captures the essence of urban solitude. The guitar's minimalistic phrasing and the subtle ambient noise create a sense of being lost in the vastness of the city. The track's slow progression mirrors the feeling of wandering without a destination, making it a poignant reflection on loneliness.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Stilled Wind
trackinfo.about: Stilled Wind is a brief, yet evocative track that conjures images of a quiet breeze suddenly halted, leaving an eerie calm in its wake. The sparse guitar notes hang in the air, almost as if time has stopped, creating a moment of reflection and stillness.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Dawn on 47th
trackinfo.about: Dawn on 47th brings a slightly more hopeful tone, with its gentle guitar melody suggesting the first light of day breaking through the darkness. The track feels like a moment of quiet realization, where the night’s fears and doubts slowly fade with the rising sun.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Shadows
trackinfo.about: Shadows is a haunting track that lives up to its name, with its dark, echoing tones and minimalistic structure. The slow BPM and the subtle dissonance give the impression of figures moving silently through the darkness, unseen and unacknowledged.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: In Cushman Row
trackinfo.about: In Cushman Row captures the essence of a quiet, forgotten corner of the city. The track's minimal guitar lines and ambient background noises create a sense of isolation and reflection, as if the listener is peering into a world long since abandoned.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Cardboard Pillow
trackinfo.about: Cardboard Pillow is a deeply emotional piece, with its gentle, almost fragile guitar work evoking a sense of vulnerability. The track’s title suggests the hardships of life on the streets, and the music reflects this with its raw, unembellished sound.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: O'Connor's Last Air
trackinfo.about: O'Connor's Last Air is a somber, reflective track that seems to mourn the passing of time. The slow, deliberate guitar playing and the faint echoes in the background give the impression of a final breath, a last moment of contemplation before fading into silence.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Little Wind
trackinfo.about: Little Wind is a delicate, airy piece that feels like a gentle breeze passing through. The lightness of the guitar work and the slow BPM give the track a sense of fleeting beauty, capturing a moment that is both ephemeral and touching.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

trackinfo.title: Siren
trackinfo.about: Siren closes the album on a mysterious note, with its eerie, echoing tones and slow, deliberate pace. The track feels like a distant call from the depths, haunting and alluring, leaving the listener with a sense of unresolved tension as the album fades into silence.
trackinfo.credits: from 9th Avenue, released January 1, 1994

Loren Connors.title: Calloden Harvest
Loren Connors.about:
Calloden Harvest by Loren Mazzacane Connors is a haunting exploration of minimalist ambient soundscapes, blending the raw emotion of blues with experimental avant-garde sensibilities. The album captures a deep sense of melancholy and reflection, drawing listeners into a world where each note reverberates with profound significance. The slow, droning pace of the compositions creates an almost meditative atmosphere, allowing one to immerse fully in the textured layers of guitar work that Connors is renowned for.
!The album is a journey through solitude and introspection, where the sparse, yet powerful instrumentation evokes images of desolate landscapes and fading memories. Connors' ability to convey such depth of emotion with minimalistic arrangements is a testament to his mastery of the ambient genre. The subtle shifts in tone and the delicate interplay between silence and sound make this album a compelling experience for those who appreciate the art of restraint.
!Overall, Calloden Harvest stands as a powerful statement in Loren Mazzacane Connors' discography, demonstrating his ability to craft deeply emotional and atmospheric pieces that resonate long after the music has stopped. It is an essential listen for fans of ambient, experimental, and avant-garde music.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: Premonition
trackinfo.about: Premonition sets the tone for the album with a slow, creeping atmosphere that feels both foreboding and introspective. The delicate, yet deliberate guitar plucks create a sense of impending doom, as if something dark and inevitable is approaching. The track’s ambient qualities are underscored by its minimalistic approach, with each note hanging in the air like a whisper of what’s to come.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: Enemy
trackinfo.about: Enemy is a tense and brooding piece, where the guitar's mournful tones suggest conflict and unease. The track's slow BPM emphasizes the weight of its emotion, creating a soundscape that feels both heavy and suspenseful. It's as if the listener is caught in the middle of an unresolved struggle, with the music reflecting the uncertainty and fear that accompanies it.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: Come Death, Lord Cromwell
trackinfo.about: Come Death, Lord Cromwell is perhaps the darkest track on the album, with its slow, dirge-like pace and ominous overtones. The guitar work here is stark and unadorned, each note resonating with a sense of finality. The track feels like a funeral march, a solemn acknowledgment of loss and the inevitable passage of time.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: The Road To Drumassy
trackinfo.about: The Road To Drumassy introduces a slightly more melodic element to the album, with a gentle, almost melancholic guitar line that evokes a sense of journeying through a barren landscape. There is a subtle undercurrent of hope in the music, as if the road, despite its challenges, might lead to a place of solace.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: A Calling
trackinfo.about: A Calling feels like a moment of contemplation, where the sparse guitar notes seem to search for something just out of reach. The track’s ambient nature is accentuated by its slow tempo, creating a meditative space that invites the listener to pause and reflect. It’s a quiet, introspective piece that adds depth to the album’s overall mood.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: Wild Night
trackinfo.about: Wild Night contrasts with the previous tracks by introducing a more chaotic, almost dissonant energy. The guitar work here is more aggressive, with sharp, jarring notes that break the album’s otherwise somber tone. It’s as if the music is capturing the wildness and unpredictability of the night, a brief but intense departure from the reflective nature of the rest of the album.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: No Way Home
trackinfo.about: No Way Home brings back the sense of desolation and despair that pervades much of the album. The guitar’s mournful wail creates an atmosphere of hopelessness, as if the journey has led to a dead end. The minimalistic approach enhances the feeling of being lost, with no clear direction or resolution in sight.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

trackinfo.title: First Light
trackinfo.about: First Light closes the album on a slightly more hopeful note, with a gentle, almost serene guitar melody that suggests the dawning of a new day. The track’s ambient qualities create a sense of calm and peace, a contrast to the darker tones that dominate the album. It’s a fitting conclusion, offering a glimpse of light after a long night of darkness.
trackinfo.credits: from Calloden Harvest, released January 1, 1997

Loren Connors.title: Crucible
Loren Connors.about:
Crucible by Loren Mazzacane Connors & Suzanne Langille is a profound exploration of the raw emotional landscapes that can be sculpted through minimalistic yet deeply evocative sounds. The album resides at the intersection of experimental blues and avant-garde, creating a sound that is both hauntingly intimate and expansively atmospheric.
Each track seems to dwell in a space where the boundaries of music blur into a meditative state, driven by Loren's sparse guitar work and Suzanne's ethereal vocals. The album unfolds like a slow-burning journey through shadowed alleys and whispered thoughts, maintaining a delicate balance between dissonance and harmony.
The experimental nature of the album is not just a backdrop but the essence of its storytelling. It's an emotional crucible where each note and chord progression feels intentional, almost like a spoken word in a long-lost language of despair and hope. The drone-like qualities merge with ambient textures, creating an immersive experience that demands the listener’s full attention. This album is a quintessential listen for those who appreciate the depth of minimalistic expression in music, particularly within the realms of ambient and impressionistic soundscapes.
!
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: First Light
trackinfo.about: First Light opens the album with a somber, reflective tone. The track is a slow, meditative piece where Loren's guitar gently weeps, accompanied by Suzanne's delicate whispers. The BPM is low, around 40, enhancing the feeling of a slow dawn breaking. The mood is one of quiet contemplation, setting the stage for the emotional journey that follows.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Dimstar
trackinfo.about: Dimstar is an ambient piece with an undercurrent of melancholy. The slow, repetitive drone of the guitar, paired with Suzanne's haunting voice, creates an atmosphere of isolation. The track's BPM hovers around 35, emphasizing the dragging sensation of time. It's a stark, beautiful soundscape that evokes the feeling of staring into the abyss.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: In The Morning, Duffy Square
trackinfo.about: This track captures the desolate quiet of early morning. With a slightly higher BPM of 45, it still maintains a languid pace, but there's a subtle shift in energy. The guitar notes are sparse and measured, while Suzanne’s vocals add a layer of wistful nostalgia. The mood is introspective, perfect for solitary reflection.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Single Heart
trackinfo.about: Single Heart is a poignant piece that speaks to the listener on a deeply emotional level. The BPM is around 38, and the music carries a sense of longing. Loren's guitar plays slow, deliberate notes, while Suzanne’s vocals express a fragile hope. The atmosphere is one of yearning, making it one of the more emotionally charged tracks on the album.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Morning Doubt
trackinfo.about: Morning Doubt introduces a sense of uncertainty and introspection. With a BPM of 42, the track moves at a slightly faster pace, yet maintains the album's signature minimalistic style. The guitar chords are slightly dissonant, and Suzanne's vocals have an edge of anxiety, perfectly capturing the essence of doubt and inner conflict.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: 43rd And 8th
trackinfo.about: 43rd And 8th is a snapshot of urban loneliness. The BPM is around 40, with a rhythm that mimics the slow, dragging feet of a solitary figure walking through empty streets. Loren’s guitar is subdued, almost drowned in the ambient noises that suggest a bustling city now silent. Suzanne's voice is a distant echo, reinforcing the theme of isolation.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Pipe Dream
trackinfo.about: Pipe Dream offers a moment of respite and fantasy. The BPM is slightly higher at 44, introducing a faint sense of motion and possibility. The guitar melodies are more fluid, with a dreamlike quality, while Suzanne’s vocals are soft and ethereal. The track evokes a fleeting sense of hope, like a dream that fades upon waking.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Open Doors
trackinfo.about: Open Doors introduces a sense of transition and possibility. The BPM is around 43, with a gentle, flowing rhythm that suggests movement and change. Loren's guitar work is more expansive, and Suzanne’s vocals have a welcoming, almost hopeful tone. The track embodies the feeling of stepping into the unknown with a cautious optimism.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Crucible
trackinfo.about: The title track, Crucible, is the emotional core of the album. With a BPM of 40, it is slow and deliberate, capturing the essence of the album’s theme. The guitar is raw and unfiltered, while Suzanne’s vocals are filled with a quiet intensity. The track conveys a sense of being forged in fire, of emerging stronger but forever changed.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: O'Donnell's Camp
trackinfo.about: O'Donnell's Camp is a reflective piece that carries a strong sense of place. The BPM is around 38, and the guitar work is intricate yet restrained. Suzanne's vocals tell a story of nostalgia and memory, as if recounting a past that is both cherished and bittersweet. The mood is introspective, making it a standout track for its storytelling.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Crying Low
trackinfo.about: Crying Low is a haunting lament. The BPM is 36, slow and mournful, with Loren's guitar almost weeping in harmony with Suzanne's vocals. The track is steeped in sorrow, capturing the depth of human emotion in its most vulnerable state. The mood is one of profound sadness, making it one of the most emotionally resonant tracks on the album.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Don't Give Up Hope In Me
trackinfo.about: Don't Give Up Hope In Me is a plea for understanding and faith. The BPM is around 42, with a steady, reassuring rhythm. The guitar work is gentle and comforting, while Suzanne’s vocals are filled with a quiet desperation. The track radiates a fragile hope, a beacon in the album’s often dark emotional landscape.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

trackinfo.title: Here In The Night
trackinfo.about: Here In The Night closes the album on a note of quiet resignation. The BPM is 39, with a slow, deliberate pace that mirrors the closing of a long, contemplative journey. Loren's guitar is subdued, and Suzanne's vocals are soft, almost a whisper. The track feels like a lullaby for the weary, a final moment of peace before the end.
trackinfo.credits: from Crucible, released January 1, 1996

Loren Connors.title: Departing Of A Dream Vol III: Juliet
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Mazzacane Connors' 'Departing Of A Dream Vol III: Juliet' is a haunting exploration of sound, where each note lingers like a ghostly whisper. The album immerses listeners in a deep, ambient landscape, blending elements of experimental music with the minimalism and raw emotion of blues. This is music that drifts between worlds, capturing the ephemeral beauty of love and loss through Connors' distinctive guitar work.
!>The album’s slow, deliberate pace, with tracks that often float around a BPM of 40-60, creates a meditative atmosphere. Connors' improvisational style, combined with the drone-like qualities of the compositions, makes this album a deeply introspective experience. Each track feels like a chapter in a larger narrative, full of unresolved tension and melancholic beauty. It's an album that demands to be listened to in its entirety, as the emotional weight of each piece builds upon the last.
!> 'Departing Of A Dream Vol III: Juliet' stands out for its unique blend of sound art and blues, where the boundaries between genres blur. It's an album that will resonate with fans of ambient music, but also with anyone who appreciates the artistry of minimalism and the emotional depth of the blues. Connors' ability to convey profound emotion with such sparse arrangements is nothing short of remarkable.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 2004

Loren Connors.title: Hell's Kitchen Park
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Mazzacane Connors' *Hell's Kitchen Park* is a haunting exploration of sound, where minimalism meets the raw emotion of blues. The album immerses the listener in an eerie, yet deeply evocative atmosphere, blending ambient textures with avant-garde structures. Connors’ guitar work is sparse yet emotionally charged, each note lingering like a whispered memory. The overall mood of the album is introspective and melancholic, drawing from the dark ambient style to create an almost cinematic experience that is both meditative and unsettling.
The use of silence and space is as crucial as the notes themselves, creating a feeling of vast emptiness that resonates with the listener long after the music ends. Each track feels like a glimpse into a different facet of Connors’ emotional landscape, from the quiet reflection of 'Mother & Son' to the desolate beauty of 'Hell’s Kitchen Park.' The album’s structure and pacing contribute to its power, with slower BPMs that allow the listener to fully absorb the emotional depth of each piece.
For fans of experimental and avant-garde music, *Hell's Kitchen Park* is a profound experience. Its minimalistic approach and atmospheric qualities make it a standout in Connors' discography, offering a deep dive into the possibilities of sound as an expressive medium.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1993

Loren Connors.title: Moonyean
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Mazzacane Connors' *Moonyean* is a haunting journey through minimalist soundscapes, where bluesy melancholy intertwines with ambient textures to create an album that is both deeply personal and profoundly atmospheric. The music is steeped in a sense of solitude, each track unfolding like a whispered conversation with the night. The use of sparse guitar work and long, sustained notes lends the album an almost ethereal quality, pulling the listener into a contemplative state.
The album's experimental nature is evident in its refusal to adhere to conventional structures, favoring instead a fluid, almost improvisational approach. This gives *Moonyean* a timeless quality, as if the music exists outside of any specific era or genre. The blend of ambient, blues, and avant-garde elements creates a sound that is uniquely Connors, simultaneously meditative and disquieting.
Each track on *Moonyean* is like a brushstroke on a dark canvas, contributing to a larger picture that is mysterious and enigmatic. The minimalist approach, coupled with the drone-like qualities, invites deep listening and reflection. This is not an album that reveals itself easily; it requires patience and an openness to its subtle nuances. For those willing to delve into its depths, *Moonyean* offers a richly rewarding experience.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1994

Loren Connors.title: Rooms
Loren Connors.about:
Loren Mazzacane Connors' *Rooms* is a haunting exploration of blues through the lens of experimental and minimalistic soundscapes. The album defies traditional blues structures, instead opting for an impressionistic and lo-fi approach that resonates with deep emotional undercurrents.
The sparse instrumentation, often just a solitary guitar, creates a sense of isolation and introspection, perfectly complemented by Suzanne Langille's ethereal vocal contributions. Each track is a delicate balance of sound and silence, evoking a mood that is both melancholic and serene. The ambient elements further enhance the immersive experience, drawing the listener into a world where every note feels like a breath.
The album's freeform nature allows Connors to express his emotions without the constraints of traditional song structure, making *Rooms* a truly unique entry in the blues genre. Whether you're a fan of experimental music or simply looking for something that challenges the norm, *Rooms* offers a compelling journey through the depths of human emotion.
Loren Connors.credits: released January 1, 1990

Loren Connors.title: The Only Way To Go Is Straight Through
Loren Connors.label: Northern Spy Records
Loren Connors.about:
Thurston and Loren fearlessly dive into a hot, dark pool and enter a world of surging sound and faint lights. They can't see each other. They can only hear each others' searing notes in the heat. But it is enough to take them through.
The material on The Only Way To Go Is Straight Through was compiled from two live recordings. Side A was captured at The Stone in Manhattan, where Moore and Connors performed on July 14, 2012 for the second annual Spy Music Festival (pictured above). The pair met up again on October 17, 2012 to headline Northern Spy's CMJ showcase at Public Assembly in Brooklyn (pictured below), and that mesmerizing set became Side B of this record.
"Most guitarists who improvise with Loren Connors show the man some deference. Both Jim O’Rourke and Alan Licht have tended to orbit his Venusian blues, keeping his keening figures and nocturnal atmospheres in the center; Keiji Haino showed none of the calculated ignorance he sometimes uses to keep other musicians off balance. And while Thurston Moore certainly knows how to wail, in improvised contexts he tends to take his cues from his fellow musicians, matching their energy level. But deference was not on the agenda during either of the performances that make up this LP, which Northern Spy has pressed up for Record Store Day 2013 in a run of 3000. “The Stone (2012/07/14)” opens with a display of outright savagery; Moore chases down and destroys tones with the cruel agility of a WW I fighter pilot keeping an evasive opponent in his sites, while Connors pumps in continuous streams of sound that bulge in the middle like a boa constrictor that chowed down on a collection of bowling balls. Then they shift to a less propulsive but not less aggressive mode; Moore’s distorted squall scythes around Connors’ squelchy wah-wah licks, then attacks it directly. Connors takes the blows and strikes back; if these were comic book characters, they’d be fencing with outboard motors."
- Dusted  (www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/7676)
Loren Connors.credits:
released April 20, 2013
Artwork – Loren Connors
Mixed By, Mastered By – Chris Weiss
